Problem:
We analyze a mechanical system where the position \( x(t) \) of a mass evolves according to the differential equation \( \ddot{x} = -kx \), a simple harmonic oscillator, where \( k \) is a positive constant. We introduce transformations via \( f(x) = A \sin(Bx) \) at different instances to investigate causal influences.

Can the specific interventions applied (whether \( f(x) \), \( g(x) \), or both) be inferred precisely by knowing only the observed state \( x(T) \)?
Explanation: Given the endpoint \( x(T) \), distinguishing which transformations or sequences of transformations were applied proves complicated due to the multiple potential trajectories converging to the same final state. This stems from the complex effects introduced by the interplay of the nonlinear transformations \( f(x) \) and \( g(x) \).
